Arkite.note: Descendants of Arka, a Canaanite tribe living in Lebanon (Genesis 10:17).

Amalekite.note: A nomadic enemy nation of Israel descended from Esau (Exodus 17:8–16).

Ammonite.note: Descendants of Lot, often hostile to Israel (Deuteronomy 2:19; Judges 11:12–28).

Ammonites.note: Plural form of Ammonite, enemies of Israel; descended from Lot (Judges 10:6–9).

Amorites.note: An ancient Canaanite people who opposed Israel’s conquest of the Promised Land (Genesis 15:16).

Amorite.note: Singular of Amorites; key nation in Canaanite opposition to Israel (Joshua 10:5).

Benjamites.note: Tribe descended from Benjamin, youngest son of Jacob (Judges 20:12–48).

Canaan.note: A region and people representing the Promised Land, often spiritually symbolic (Genesis 12:5–7).

Canaanite.note: Inhabitants of Canaan, representing idolatrous opposition to Israel (Exodus 3:8).

Canaanites.note: Plural form of Canaanite; native nations of the Promised Land (Deuteronomy 7:1).

Casluhim.note: Descendants of Mizraim; ancestors of the Philistines (Genesis 10:14).

Chaldeans.note: People of southern Babylon; associated with astrology and conquest (Daniel 2:2; Isaiah 13:19).

Cherethites.note: A group allied with the Philistines; served as royal guards for David (2 Samuel 8:18).

Gentiles.note: A broad term for non-Israelite nations, often symbolic of the world (Romans 11:13; Matthew 10:5).

Hivite.note: A Canaanite tribe that made a deceptive peace with Israel (Joshua 9:7).

Horite.note: Mountain-dwelling people in Seir before Esau’s descendants (Genesis 36:20).

Horites.note: Mountain-dwelling people in Seir before Esau’s descendants (Genesis 36:20).

Ishmaelites.note: Descendants of Ishmael; associated with trade and conflict with Israel (Genesis 37:25–28).

Jebusite.note: A Canaanite people who inhabited Jerusalem before its conquest by David (2 Samuel 5:6–7).

Maachathi.note: People of Maacah, a small kingdom near Bashan; allies or enemies in regional conflicts (Deuteronomy 3:14).

Maonites.note: Nomadic group opposing Israel during the time of the Judges; possibly linked to Midianites (Judges 10:12).

Emims.note: A giant people feared by the Moabites, described as Rephaim; lived in the region of Moab (Deuteronomy 2:10–11).

Gammadims.note: Skilled warriors or defenders from a region called Gammad; served in Tyre's army (Ezekiel 27:11).

Jairite.note: A descendant of Jair; also refers to Ira the Jairite, David's priest (2 Samuel 20:26).

Jew.note: A member of the tribe of Judah or later, any Israelite; term expands to mean God's covenant people (Esther 2:5; Romans 2:29).

Nethinims.note: Temple servants assigned to aid Levites, possibly of foreign origin; descendants of the Gibeonites (Ezra 2:43–58).

Midianites.note: Descendants of Abraham through Keturah; alternately allies and enemies of Israel (Judges 6:1; Exodus 2:15–21).

Pathrusim.note: Descendants of Mizraim (Egypt); settled in Pathros, southern Egypt (Genesis 10:14).

Perizzite.note: A Canaanite group living in rural areas of the Promised Land (Genesis 13:7; Judges 1:4–5).

Philistine.note: A key enemy nation of Israel along the coast; known for conflicts with judges and kings (1 Samuel 17:1).

Philistines.note: Plural of Philistine; major adversaries in Israel’s early monarchy period (Judges 13:1).

Rephaim.note: Race of ancient giants; associated with fear and spiritual symbolism (Deuteronomy 2:11; Genesis 14:5).

Syrian.note: Individual from the region of Aram; played both hostile and neutral roles in Israel's history (2 Kings 5:1–14).

Syrians.note: Plural of Syrian; nation often in conflict with Israel (2 Samuel 10:6–19).

Samaritan.note: Inhabitants of Samaria; viewed as mixed and unclean by Jews post-exile (John 4:9; 2 Kings 17:24–41).

Temanites.note: Descendants of Teman, son of Eliphaz; known for wisdom and location in Edom (Job 2:11; Jeremiah 49:7).

Ziphites.note: People from Ziph in Judah; betrayed David to Saul during his flight (1 Samuel 23:19–24).

Zuzims.note: Ancient people group, possibly giants; defeated by Chedorlaomer’s army (Genesis 14:5).

Zidonians.note: The people of the ancient city of Sidon, often in reference to those who worshiped Baal (1 Kings 16:31).

Armenia.note: Region historically located near Mount Ararat, associated with early biblical narratives.

Assyria.note: Ancient empire located in Mesopotamia, often depicted as an oppressor of Israel.

Avim.note: Ancient people inhabiting southern Canaan, displaced by Philistine migrations.

Corinthia.note: Region surrounding ancient Corinth, significant early Christian community.

Edom.note: Nation descended from Esau, historically hostile to Israel.

Egypt.note: Prominent ancient civilization, significant in Israel’s history for enslavement and Exodus.

Ethiopia.note: Ancient kingdom south of Egypt, known biblically as Cush.

Girgashites.note: One of the ancient Canaanite tribes displaced by the Israelites.

Greece.note: Prominent ancient civilization influential in culture and mentioned frequently in the New Testament.

Hittites.note: Ancient civilization in Anatolia, significant rivals and neighbors of early Israel.

Hivites.note: Canaanite people group encountered and displaced by the Israelites.

children of Israel.note: Nation formed from the descendants of Jacob (Israel), central to biblical narrative.

Jebusites.note: Canaanite inhabitants of Jerusalem before its conquest by King David.

Moabites.note: Descendants of Moab, historically adversarial neighbors east of Israel.

Perizzites.note: One of the Canaanite tribes occupying land promised to Israel.

Persians.note: Empire ruling after Babylon, known for allowing Jewish return from exile.

Gadites.note: Tribe descended from Gad, one of Jacob's sons; settled east of the Jordan River.

Sheba.note: Ancient kingdom, possibly located in modern-day Yemen, famous for the visit of its queen to Solomon.

Sinim.note: Region mentioned prophetically in Isaiah, possibly referring to distant eastern lands, potentially China.

Syria.note: Ancient nation north of Israel, frequently interacting politically and militarily with biblical Israel.
